wordpressPost.title: Are you losing your hair at middle-age?
wordpressPost.content:
Are you losing your hair at middle-age? ¬†If so, you should get your hormones and nutrient levels checked.

Low thyroid, poor digestion, nutrient deficiencies such as iron, vitamin B, hormonal issues, aging, trauma and stress can create hair loss and hair thinning.

If you are losing large amounts of hair you should get to your doctor ASAP because you may have an underlying disease.

Once you get your levels checked and your doctor has made any changes as necessary, some of the suggestions for nutritional therapy are as follows:

  • Flaxseed Oil
  • Biotin
  • Zinc
  • Amino Acid Blends
  • Vitamin B Complex
  • Iron (if needed) I needed iron and didn’t even know it!

If you have dull and lifeless hair, use primrose oil, flaxseed oil and vitamin E in the evening.

Even poor liver functioning can play a role in hair loss. ¬†If this is your case then consider using a liver supplement.

A good therapy for hair loss is a juice therapy of:

  • Carrots
  • Beets
  • Spinach
  • Nettle
  • Alfalfa

Once you get your hormones in check and you have ingested the proper supplements, you can do massage scalp therapy with your fingers, nightly.

Genetics, diet and the way you treat your hair can also be the reason you’re losing your hair too.

I wish I had luxurious long hair but, I look at my mom and she has baby fine hair. I’m thinking that I will probably end up more like my mom.

I also color my hair and use the straightener a little too often which makes my hair break.

My diet is really good as I only eat fish and vegetables but, I probably drink way too much wine.

I know if I changed most of these things, my hair would be in much better shape but the trade off is, I kind of like my life and I can deal with my hair loss because of it.

Hope for Thinning Hair

“Research continues to dispel the notion that some types of hair loss are permanent. Experts at the University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine, for example, recently found that people who struggle with hair loss don‚Äôt have dead follicle stem cells, as previously feared ‚Äî just malfunctioning follicle stem cells, which may be fixable. And another study found that mice with deep skin wounds could regrow hair, sparking hope for a cure for baldness in humans.” (http://www.everydayhealth.com/womens-health/woman-dealing-with-hair-loss.aspx)

I think there will be a stem cell or other therapy coming very soon to stop hair loss. ¬†It may not stop the breakage from the damage that we do to our hair but it may stop the loss at the follicle. I’ll be patiently waiting üôÇ
